awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Platform for Health Care Data Integration Using Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact /commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to improve health outcomes while managing costs.   The proposed technology enables the integration and retrieval of data from many places and formats across a distributed ecosystem secured by blockchain. Healthcare, a $2.9 B market segment, is targeted because the need is great and the US healthcare market is highly fragmented. Making healthcare data faster to interoperate and share while maintaining data integrity, security and privacy is key to potentially improving healthcare outcomes. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is advancing foundational technology for searching and retrieving heterogeneous data secured in blockchain across a distributed data platform. Multiple data sources with different formats and data models will be transformed into more granular data blocks in blockchain. In addition to normalizing blockchain data into more granular data blocks for sharing and re-use in different applications (i.e., simplifying data integration and interoperability), research will use natural language processing (NLP) to assist in automatically generating metadata tags to facilitate searching across blockchains. To improve the accuracy of data returned in the search, a human expert-curated healthcare dictionary and thesaurus will be created and used in concert with NLP assistance. This combined approach should improve the accuracy of data retrieval by non-IT, healthcare, users across a secure, peer-to-peer data platform where data owners retain full ownership and control of their data. The proposed research will also validate through performance testing new blockchain search capabilies will meet the responsiveness and scale required by healthcare enterprises, a key need for commercialization. In particular, the project will establish benchmarks for speed and latency across a geographically dispersed network.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
emTRUTH Enablies Radical Interoperabiity

NSF SBIR Phase I - Project Outcomes Report

Healthcare always has and always will need data from many different systems, in many different formats and sizes. Because that is what is needed to provide patients with the best care. Data is at the heart of digital health and achieving value-based care that improves patient outcomes and manages costs. Currently, much of healthcare data is silo’ed, even within one organization. Securely sharing the right data, with the right people, at the right time is very expensive and requires many specialized IT skills which are already stretched thin. Trying to do this outside an organization’s four walls (e.g., with integrated delivery network partners) is near impossible for all but organizations with tremendous resources at their disposal.

emTRUTH proposed a Phase I creating a prototype, called emVP (empowering Valued Patients), that integrates blockchain technology and natural language processing (NLP) to enable healthcare users to securely combine, share and analyze data of any size or format from many places, on demand; allowing health experts to bypass waiting for scarce IT resources. The ability to rapidly integrate and make interoperable heterogeneous data, structured and unstructured, would be transformative for healthcare while data owners retain their respective ownership and control of their data.

Phase I Objectives: The purpose of Phase I A Platform for Health Care Data Integration Using Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence was to demonstrate the feasibility of the following.

  1. Ability to integrate and make interoperable data from many sources, in many shapes and sizes.
  2. Capturing multi-source data in blockchain to facilitate re-use of data for other purposes while maintaining data ownership and control by respective data owners.
  3. Usefulness of applying Natural Language Processing (NLP) and a curated thesaurus to facilitate automated self-contained metadata tagging of data captured in blockchain.
  4. Usefulness of applying NLP and curated thesaurus to facilitate searching of data captured in blockchain
  5. Maintaining performance on prototype data platform architecture with addition of self-contained metadata tags.
  6. Development of a prototype emVP (empowering Valued Patients) that demonstrates research objectives with an easy-to-use interface suitable for non-Information Technology (IT) experts.

Phase I Results include:

  • A patent covering innovation resulting from Phase I, also registered with NSF iEdison, has been filed.
  • An emVP prototype platform for data aggregation and easy to use interface for non-technical users to search, aggregate, tag, securely share and analyze healthcare data of any type from any source.
  • Automated metadata tagging of data in blockchain and searching facilitated by NLP and a curated thesaurus for searching and aggregating data captured in blockchain. emTRUTH achieved over 90% success rate of accurately tagging data in blockchains.
  • Created a human-readable and easy to implement Blockchain Connector Language (BCL) for transforming and normalizing source data into underlying, more granular blockchains, and for transforming blockchains into formats immediately consumable by source applications. This enables radical interoperability in less time and at less cost.
  • Proof of concept for BCL as a rapidly scalable transformation and normalization approach across disparate domains like health conditions and ethnicity. Transformed a global COVID-19 Intensive Care Unit (ICU) registry data dictionary into OMOP and CDISC both well-established clinical research standards. Phase I objective was to demonstrate feasibility with 25 data elements. emTRUTH achieved over 18,000 data elements in Phase I.
  • Maintains data ownership and full access control while securely sharing with various users. Blockchains are created under the ownership of each respective data owner.
  • Demonstrated through performance testing that emVP performs thousands of transactions per second even with additional metadata tagging for search, retrieval, and aggregation. 

emTRUTH successfully achieved all SBIR Phase I objectives. Enabling seamless data interoperability is foundational to better patient outcomes and managing costs. Because healthcare data is and should be protected, using blockchain and AI as enabling technologies allows secure sharing of the right data, with the right people, at the right time. In addition to helping individual patients, harmonized data also helps society by making this data, ethically and with consent, more readily available for advanced work in healthcare like population modeling and social determinants of health, which results in more inclusive and representative options. Inclusion and data truly representative of the population is key to improving health equity, including data used to train many of the AI-based models in use or in development today.

For more information about emTRUTH, please visit our website www.emtruth.com or contact info@emtruth.com

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2023
Modified by: Irene W Woerner
